thread.title: In a time of progress, dramatizing a gay rights landmark
thread.title_full: In a time of progress, dramatizing a gay rights landmark

author: JAKE COYLE
title: In a time of progress, dramatizing a gay rights landmark
text:
Victoria Will In a time of progress, dramatizing a gay rights landmark 
In this Sept. 28, 2015 photo, Julianne Moore, left, and Ellen Page pose for a portrait to promote their upcoming film "Freeheld" in New York. (Photo by Victoria Will/Invision/AP) Phil Caruso In a time of progress, dramatizing a gay rights landmark 
In this image released by Lionsgate, Julianne Moore, left, and Ellen Page appear in a scene from "Freeheld." (Phil Caruso/Lionsgate via AP) Phil Caruso In a time of progress, dramatizing a gay rights landmark 
In this image released by Lionsgate, Julianne Moore, left, and Ellen Page appear in a scene from "Freeheld." (Phil Caruso/Lionsgate via AP) Phil Caruso In a time of progress, dramatizing a gay rights landmark 
In this image released by Lionsgate, Ellen Page appears in a scene from "Freeheld." (Phil Caruso/Lionsgate via AP) Posted: Wednesday, September 30, 2015 1:33 pm | Updated: 4:01 pm, Wed Sep 30, 2015. In a time of progress, dramatizing a gay rights landmark Associated Press | 
TORONTO (AP) — "Freeheld," a gay-rights drama about the turning tide of social justice, was shaped by the same currents of change it depicts. 
In the course of making the true story about New Jersey police detective Laurel Hester's fight for pension benefits for her domestic partner, Stacie Andree, the Supreme Court ruled in favor of marriage equality and one of the film's stars, Ellen Page, came out.
